In this case, P represents "the book was written by James" and Q represents "the book is a mystery novel." We are given that the first statement (the conditional) is true, and we are also given that the second statement (Q) is true. In modus ponens, if both the conditional and Q are true, then Q must be true. However, this does not necessarily mean that P is true. It could be the case that the book is a mystery novel, but not because it was written by James. It could have been written by someone else. Therefore, while it is likely that the book was written by James, we cannot be completely sure based on the given information.
